slides.title: Welcome to Stellar Astronomy
slides.content:
# Introduction to Stellar Astronomy

Welcome to **Stellar Astronomy** - the life of stars!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Star Properties** - Measuring stars
- **Star Formation** - Birth of stars
- **Main Sequence** - Hydrogen burning
- **Evolution** - Changes over time
- **End States** - Death of stars

> **Fun Fact:** The Sun loses 4 million tons of mass every second through fusion!

slides.title: Stellar Properties
slides.content:
# Measuring Stars

## Key Properties:

| Property | How Measured |
|----------|-------------|
| Distance | Parallax, standard candles |
| Luminosity | Distance + brightness |
| Temperature | Color, spectral lines |
| Mass | Binary star orbits |
| Radius | Eclipsing binaries |

## Magnitude Scale:
- Apparent magnitude: How bright it looks
- Absolute magnitude: Intrinsic brightness
- Lower number = brighter

## Distance:
- Parallax: Nearby stars
- 1 parsec = 3.26 light-years

slides.title: Spectral Classification
slides.content:
# Spectral Classification

## OBAFGKM Sequence:

| Class | Temperature | Color | Example |
|-------|------------|-------|--------|
| O | >30,000 K | Blue | Zeta Orionis |
| B | 10,000-30,000 | Blue-white | Rigel |
| A | 7,500-10,000 | White | Sirius |
| F | 6,000-7,500 | Yellow-white | Procyon |
| G | 5,200-6,000 | Yellow | Sun |
| K | 3,700-5,200 | Orange | Arcturus |
| M | <3,700 | Red | Betelgeuse |

## Memory Aid:
Oh Be A Fine Girl/Guy, Kiss Me!

slides.title: HR Diagram
slides.content:
# Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram

## Axes:
- X-axis: Temperature (hot left, cool right)
- Y-axis: Luminosity (bright top, dim bottom)

## Main Features:

| Region | Stars |
|--------|-------|
| Main sequence | Normal H-burning stars |
| Giants | Red, expanded stars |
| Supergiants | Very massive, luminous |
| White dwarfs | Small, hot remnants |

## Uses:
- Determine stellar evolution
- Estimate distances
- Understand populations

slides.title: Star Formation
slides.content:
# Star Formation

## Process:
1. **Giant molecular cloud** collapses
2. **Protostar** forms in dense core
3. **Accretion disk** feeds the star
4. **Nuclear fusion** begins
5. **Main sequence** reached

## Triggers:
- Shock waves from supernovae
- Galaxy collisions
- Density waves in spiral arms

## Timescale:
- Massive stars: ~100,000 years
- Sun-like: ~10 million years
- Small stars: ~100 million years

## Young Stars:
- T Tauri stars (low mass)
- Herbig Ae/Be (intermediate)

slides.title: Nuclear Fusion
slides.content:
# Nuclear Fusion in Stars

## Hydrogen Burning:

**Proton-proton chain (like Sun):**
```
4H -> He + energy
```

**CNO cycle (hot stars):**
- Uses carbon as catalyst
- Dominant above 15 million K

## Energy Production:
- E = mc^2
- 0.7% mass converted to energy
- Sun: 4 million tons/second

## Conditions:
- Core temperature: 15 million K
- High pressure
- Quantum tunneling required

slides.title: Main Sequence Lifetime
slides.content:
# Main Sequence Phase

## Definition:
Period of stable hydrogen burning.

## Lifetime:
- Depends on mass
- More massive = shorter life
- Burn fuel faster

## Approximate Lifetimes:

| Mass | Lifetime |
|------|----------|
| 30 Msun | 6 million years |
| 10 Msun | 30 million years |
| 1 Msun (Sun) | 10 billion years |
| 0.5 Msun | 50 billion years |
| 0.1 Msun | 10 trillion years |

## Sun's Age:
- 4.6 billion years old
- About halfway through

slides.title: Red Giant Phase
slides.content:
# Post-Main Sequence: Red Giants

## What Happens:
1. Core hydrogen exhausted
2. Core contracts, heats up
3. Shell hydrogen burning
4. Outer layers expand and cool
5. Star becomes red giant

## Sun as Red Giant:
- Will happen in ~5 billion years
- Expand to Mercury's orbit
- Vaporize inner planets

## Helium Flash:
- Core reaches 100 million K
- Helium fusion ignites suddenly
- Horizontal branch phase follows

slides.title: Advanced Nuclear Burning
slides.content:
# Advanced Fusion Stages

## Helium Burning:
```
3 He -> C (triple-alpha)
C + He -> O
```

## Massive Stars (>8 Msun):

| Stage | Product | Duration |
|-------|---------|----------|
| H burning | He | Millions of years |
| He burning | C, O | Hundreds of thousands |
| C burning | Ne, Mg | Thousands |
| Ne burning | O, Mg | Years |
| O burning | Si, S | Months |
| Si burning | Fe | Days |

## Why Iron Ends?
- Iron fusion ABSORBS energy
- Core collapses

slides.title: White Dwarfs
slides.content:
# White Dwarfs

## Formation:
- Low/medium mass stars (<8 Msun)
- Shed outer layers (planetary nebula)
- Core becomes white dwarf

## Properties:
- Mass: ~0.6 Msun typical
- Size: Earth-sized
- Density: 1 ton per teaspoon
- Composition: Carbon/oxygen

## Electron Degeneracy:
- Electrons resist compression
- Supports against gravity

## Chandrasekhar Limit:
- Maximum mass: 1.4 Msun
- Above: Collapse to neutron star

## Cooling:
- No fusion, just radiating heat
- Eventually become black dwarfs

slides.title: Supernovae
slides.content:
# Supernovae

## Type II (Core Collapse):
- Massive stars (>8 Msun)
- Iron core collapses
- Neutron star or black hole forms
- Outer layers explode

## Type Ia (Thermonuclear):
- White dwarf in binary
- Exceeds Chandrasekhar limit
- Runaway fusion
- Complete destruction
- Standard candle (same brightness)

## Effects:
- Creates heavy elements
- Triggers star formation
- Enriches interstellar medium

## Famous Supernovae:
- SN 1987A (Large Magellanic Cloud)
- Crab Nebula (1054 AD)

slides.title: Neutron Stars and Black Holes
slides.content:
# Compact Remnants

## Neutron Stars:
- Mass: 1.4-2 Msun
- Radius: ~10 km
- Density: Nuclear density
- Pulsars: Rotating, beaming radio

## Black Holes:
- From stars >20-25 Msun
- Singularity + event horizon
- Nothing escapes
- Stellar mass: 3-100 Msun

## Comparison:
| Type | From | Size |
|------|------|------|
| White dwarf | <8 Msun | Earth |
| Neutron star | 8-25 Msun | City |
| Black hole | >25 Msun | Singularity |

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Stellar Astronomy Summary

## Spectral Types:
- OBAFGKM (hot to cool)
- Sun is G-type (yellow)

## Life Cycle:
1. Cloud collapse
2. Main sequence (H burning)
3. Red giant (He burning)
4. End state (depends on mass)

## End States:
| Mass | Fate |
|------|------|
| <8 Msun | White dwarf |
| 8-25 Msun | Neutron star |
| >25 Msun | Black hole |

## Key Processes:
- Nuclear fusion
- Supernovae
- Degeneracy pressure

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Stellar Astronomy!
